reviewText: An enjoyable action-RPG. The game is initially somewhat difficult due to a lack of ranged weapon availability. Once you pick one up though things become much easier. It's WASD controls with keys assigned to weapon swap, dodge and block. You have a special meter that allows you to use skills you unlock at 1st, 5th, 10th, and 15th. Each class has specific weapons it can use along with 4 skills. There are generic weapons / armor etc. that all classes can use as well. There are four classes from which to choose with a variety of loot to collect and equip. You earn dragon scrolls by playing new adventures that you can use to 'Fight the Dragon'. This beast starts with 1 million HP and you can use multiple dragon scrolls to whittle down his health. You will die multiple times but are rewarded based on the amount of damage you can do before biting the dust. The dragon's HP is persistent so next time you'll whittle it away even more...The adventure creation kit is fun and easy to use and is the real draw of this - creating, sharing and downloading adventures. There is an excellent feedback system so you can see how many folks have played your adventures, the ratings they provided and any feedback / comments they have to help you improve. Online multiplayer co-op is available as well though I have not tried it.\n\nTL;DR : Enjoyable loot-based ARPG. Easy to use adventure creation kit that you can share with friends to play co-op. Persistent dragon HP mechanic is interesting as you do all you can over the course of your adventures to take it down.

Community is small and friendly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fight the Dragon is a fun little hack n' slash with very basic, Gauntlet-style gameplay. The game is entirely built around player made levels and designed to be played in short bursts, with each level lasting 15 minutes on average. The four available classes are differentiated by each having 4 abilities (in addition to basic attacking), as well as some unique weapon types that are only useable by certain classes.

The lack of combat depth may turn some people off but it comes down to personal preference. The adventure creator is easy to use and offers a lot of freedom, with more content being added on a regular basis. At the time of this writing, they've even begun adding a logic system to the creator as well. The game is great for picking up and running through some adventures in your down time where as making levels can keep you busy for hours on end.

FTD isn't perfect and has it's issues. The entire game's entertainment value relies on the quality of maps and the variety of tools available to those who make the maps. That being said, the devs are very attentive and really seem to care about making the game better and better. They listen to community feedback and continue to polish and add to the game, pushing out great patches on a quite regular basis. Overall I don't see much to complain about. The game is a fun little gem to spend time in and has the potential for a lot of replayability. I look forward to seeing FTD grow and hopefully its community will as well.

9/10 for Early Access gaming. It also looks like they update pretty regularly, which is promising for early access.

date:
go on an adventure or battle the dragon which requires a dragon scroll. Once I beat the developer made levels it started to put me into community made levels which made me nervous but it turns out that the devs don't like garbage levels polluting their game. Which is good. At this point I realised that this game is "never ending" because you can create your own adventures or play other adventures after you played the developer ones.
The level creation tool deserves more credit than it gets as you can do a lot with the triggers and events. Sadly I have not tried to play this with multiplayer so I cannot give a review on that.
Pros:
Lots of good unique levels
Level editor
Character customization
Nice graphical feel
Cons:
I can see how some people can find this game repetative.

Games this is similar to:
Spiral Knights and (barely) Little Big Planet. More so to spiral knights."

reviewText:
One of the best ARPGs if you ask me.
Looks a bit like a lego game.
Loot's a bit like torchlight/diablo, etc.
Levels are a bit like......well.....whatever the level creator decided it would be like. (Levels are user-created with the in-game editor, and there are many talented level designers out there in the Fight The Dragon community)
Combat is a bit more varied than many other ARPGs. It actually takes some skill, and different tactics.
The weapons have a bit of a different feel too. Some different weapon types like wands, tomes, spears, crystals and shurikens make an appearance.
This game is one of my all time favourites on any system.
If you want a cute-looking, fast-paced, unique game, without a million game mechanics to memorize, and with an ever growing number of bite-sized levels to play, AND an awesome level creation tool to tinker with......get this game!!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game could easily slip under your radar, but please don't let it! The developer of Fight The Dragon has really put forth a lot of effort in making an amazing game. The player-generated content means an endless supply of content, but that doesn't mean the developer took the lazy way out. They are constantly releasing updates to this game with new content, polish, and bug fixes. -And don't let me mislead you, either... There have been very few bugs so far! The small amount of bugs that have come up are squashed quickly, though.

The level editor is an absolute blast, too! Please be sure to check it out, even if you wouldn't normally be the type to create levels. It's surprisingly powerful, yet extremely easy to use.

I personally give this a 7/10. I only count off for the low number of monsters available at this stage, but they are quickly adding more. The dragon also needs some kind of purpose, considering the game's name. Right now, the dragon is just... there. You can fight him, but you are only fighting to see how much damage you can muster. There is no reward if you do kill him just yet. So again, 7/10 until they add some reason to all this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game could easily slip under your radar, but please don't let it! The developer of Fight The Dragon has really put forth a lot of effort in making an amazing game. The player-generated content means an endless supply of content, but that doesn't mean the developer took the lazy way out. They are constantly releasing updates to this game with new content, polish, and bug fixes. -And don't let me mislead you, either... There have been very few bugs so far! The small amount of bugs that have come up are squashed quickly, though.

The level editor is an absolute blast, too! Please be sure to check it out, even if you wouldn't normally be the type to create levels. It's surprisingly powerful, yet extremely easy to use.

I personally give this a 7/10. I only count off for the low number of monsters available at this stage, but they are quickly adding more. The dragon also needs some kind of purpose, considering the game's name. Right now, the dragon is just... there. You can fight him, but you are only fighting to see how much damage you can muster. There is no reward if you do kill him just yet. So again, 7/10 until they add some reason to all this.

reviewText:
I can't help but love Fight the Dragon.

It's Diablo without the hassle. It's a game with core mechanics so simple you can understand them within minutes. It's you and some friends wading through a challenging adventure which likely none of you have seen before.

If I wanted a deep fantasy RPG with strong characters and a thick plot, I'd go and play Dragon Age. What we have here is something very different ‚Äì a game that you can pick up and play without all of that traditional RPG baggage. Grab a few friends, hit 'random level', and give it a go. I challenge you not to have fun.

reviewText:
I'm in love with this game, and I had no intention of buying it. I trader just offered this game, I never heard of it, so I looked at some lets plays and I accepted the trade. I was gonna keep it for profit but I really wanted to play it, so I added it to my library, and I'm glad I did.

Go trough hundreds of user generated levels, get some dragon scrolls and once you think you are ready, then you can fight the dragon, hence the name.

Don't Worry, you don't need to kill the dragon, I don't know if you need to last long enough or do as much damage before you die, but whatever it is. You get good reward that can only be obtained from fighting the dragon. I'm sure you get the best rewards by killing the dragon, but I'm only level 6. That will take HOURS before I can kill it.

The user generated levels are great. There are 2 categories. Adventure and Campaign. Campaign is just like adventure but with more indepth story and multiple levels.

The only negative thing I can say right now is the multiplayer.. If you could call it that.  There are barely anyone online (about 0-4, in a good day), and most of the people online are level 60+ and as beginner, that will completely remove the challenge and fun from the game. Luckily, when hosting your game, you can put a minimum and a maximum levels that can join you, but no one would join because there are almost no people online. That's not the devs fault though.
ITS YOUR FAULT FOR NOT BUYING THIS GAME!! BUY IT NOW!

reviewText:
Despite all of its flaws, this is still one of my favorite games to play with my friends. There is so much fun to be had just exploring and plundering the various missions and dungeons that people have made for this game, ranging from open-world style exploration minions to dungeon crawling and boss rushes. The level editor is simple and easy to use, with the ability to build story into them with NPCs and whatnot giving the game ridiculous longevity.

The game isn't perfect, though. The UI takes a little bit of getting used to, and the combat is pretty lacklustre. Not to mention the game's survival is dependent on the support of its player base.

TL;DR version:

Pros:
- Lots of variety in levels
- Great to play with friends
- Finding new loot is addictive and exciting
- Good variety in the different classes

Cons:
- Combat leaves a bit to be desired
- Can't easily search for specific levels to play with friends

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First a quick result: 8.5/10, the game is definitely worth the price.  FUN to play both in SOLO mode and Multiplayer mode.
The game looks promising, has a few glitches but I am literally still suprised as many other early access games have many glitches and options ingame are limited.
The main idea is go on adventures to gain dragon scrolls, loot and xp to get enough power to defeat THE DRAGON SOLO.
Fight The Dragon is still in early access but still manages to impress me in many ways. Firstly, the game has a variety of skills and classes such as a firelord, fighter. It also has a variety of weapons, armour and special skills that requires you to be in a specific class BUT NOT TO WORRY SINCE YOU CAN CREATE MORE THAN ONE CHARACTER. The leveling up mechanics is impressive and it makes sure that gaining XP isn't easy nor hard. The system it uses to go on adventures(or dungeons) is all based on other player's creation. EVEN YOU CAN MAKE A MAP and have it featured.
The cons are the few glitches and the servers are generally mediocre and you cannot host locally YET.
THE GAME GETS MANY PATCHES( 0~90 Mb) and everytime there's an update, I get more impressed. More features are still being developed, so expect the game to get more interesting and fun.

IMO, it is worth the money and future looks promising :-)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What makes Fight The Dragon really special - and the reason I purchased it - is its adventure editor (i.e. level editor). If you have always dreamt of building small fantasy adventures, this will be your dream come true. It is so intuitive to use that anyone can be super creative with it, regardless of your techcred.

As for the game, it is a cute ARPG that may satisfy those who have always wanted to try that kind of game withouth delving into (insert your favourite ARPG here). It is pretty basic but fun for 10 min sessions.

But, really, it is the editor that makes it. It will be interesting to see how much power and flexibilty we get when the game releases, without loosing the amazing accessibility.

Now if you'll excuse me, I will jump back in and build one of my most memorable Dark Souls moment and get fellow players to suffer through my levels, but in more blocky form.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To the Dev's,

Guys, we need a way to respond to feedback in-game from players who've run through our maps.  Also, the search mechanism for choosing adventures needs work.  There have been several complaints about not being able to search for maps based on user defined tags.  Further, it seems only the top rated maps are visible to players when they're searching for adventures to run.  How can an adventure rise to the top of the ratings if no one can find it?  Please fix these issues so that we are incentivized to continue adding content and telling our friends about this, otherwise, gem of a game!

Respectfully,
The Rebel Raven

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After about 6 hours of playing the game, i think i have a pretty decent feel on where it stands and how it works ^_^

This game is 99% user created content and that can go both ways. your experience can either be fantastic or dreadful depending on the community maps you get. In MY experience i have had very few maps that i hated and quite honestly most of the maps are actually really good!

lets get into the pros and cons!
Pros:
-easy to use level creation kit
-game is great for both short and long play sessions
-will have steam workshop content in the future (ie skins and other customization features)
-very fun multiplayer
-its gauntlet meets little big planet!

Cons:
- the movement can be a little odd to get used to at first, it feels rather stiff
- the evasion mechanic can use some work as it will NOT interrupt your current attack. your choice is either tank to deal damage or evade to do none
- spell casters in the game still feel like melee classes, this here is a huge problem for me because it makes it feel like the game caters to more tanky characters (ie warrior)
-some levels you recieve are outright horrible/cannot be completed (however you CAN delete the map, exit, and block the creator/map from showing up again!)

All in all, i would say this game is a must buy if you were EVER a fan of gauntlet or little big planet. you are given a lot of freedom with the in game creation kit, and with the steam workshop and further development i see a real gem on our hands.

As long as they sort out that evasion issue and make the caster classes a bit more diverse, AND add some more creatures and tile-sets to the game (or at least allow us to via steam workshop) this game has insane potential.

8/10 (score can improve with further development)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf all you could think about while slaying your way through Diablo, Dark Alliance or Torchlight was, I wish there was a game that let me make my own dungeons and adventures
date: then this is the game for you.\n\nWell, sort of. Fight the Dragon is made for dungeons that take less than a half hour to complete, and the terrain and dungeon-building tools are very Lego or Minecraft-esque. They're still smoothing out the combat (which takes more cues from Gauntlet than modern ARPGs), adding more tilesets and enemies, and developing more classes. But it's a thoroughly pleasant experience for an Early Access game. The dungeon-building is intuitive and well-developed, even at this stage. Updates and regular and substansial, and the developers respond to player feedback. Highly reccomended, especially if, like me, you enjoyed the park builder in Tony Hawk's Pro Skater or the dungeon builder in Neverwinter more than the actual game.

reviewText:
Playing as a warrior is so dreadfully dull that I'd rather go play a sports game, and I haven't played a sports game of my own volition since probably Tecmo Bowl on the NES.

Pros:
-Workshop support
-Multiplayer (didn't try it, though)
-Create your own content

Cons:
-Base content is dreadfully paced and not very exciting
-Weak character creation options without utilizing workshop content
-Terrible interface; the inventory menu is one of the worst I've ever seen
-Terrible controls for most aspects of the game, including inventory management
-Terrible tutorial expalining how things like the shrine work (I'm assuming I can only donate once an adventure)
-Combat (at least for warriors) is mostly just clicking in place until you or your aggressors are dead
-Aiming in combat is kind of wonky, and the animations don't really adjust mid swing, so you're often swinging at air
-Jumping and climbing is cumbersome at points

Final Thoughts:
Why would you put a station (a backpack) near your house to access your inventory? It literally just hits tab for you. You can access your inventory anywhere, it just doesn't look like one. Just play Diablo, Torchlight, Minecraft or anything else.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I try to keep my fascination with video games under wraps..it's such a loaded topic it makes religion and politics look positively benign. Some things are just too hot to discuss on social media.
And as much as I love dungeon crawlers and space games, I have to admit they usually don't hold my interest. World of Warcraft was an exception, but after leveling five characters to 80 my heart just wasn't in it any more.
I like to MAKE things, not just play with things other people made..no matter how cool they are. No dungeon crawling fulfills me like painting does, no space battles are as challenging as writing a good song.
With Fight the Dragon that may have changed..
This is a game that you make yourself.
Sure, there are hundreds of levels already made, but you have access to the exact same editor the developers use. Build your dungeon brick by brick. Devise devious traps, puzzles, and mazes. Populate your level with enemies ranging from fire beetles to skeleton archers, each with their own behavior and AI.
Make pools of lava, poison, or mud. Rivers of water and bridges with trapdoors. Gates that open if you find the right key. Pressure plates that trigger walls of fire. NPCs that guide the player along their way.
Then when you finish making your level, you can publish it. Your level will be played and voted on by other Fight the Dragon players around the world.
It's much more fun to make a game than to play a game, and if your kids are into games but you worry that it's not an intellectually stimulating pursuit, you might do well to buy them a copy of Fight the Dragon.
And if you're like me and tend to like the idea of games more than games themselves, buy it for yourself. Spend a few hours in video-game legoland and I'll bet you'll be as excited as I am.
We finally have the keys to the castle!

reviewText: This game gets boring after a while. There's a few hillarious bugs in the game that made me laugh my head off, but that's basically the best part. There are some very challenging and fun dungeons, but most of them are easy as heck, even though they shouldn't be. Why? Crossbows. You basically just need a crossbow and some decent juking strats and kiting strats if things get out of hand, because crossbows can stun enemies. They're basically unbalanced. Also, Fighting the Dragon is kinda boring. It has 4 basic moves that you can all dodge easily except for one of them, and 2 op abilities that can half shot you at level 15ish that you can dodge easily. There's also a bug that you can get while fighting the dragon, maybe in dungeons too. If you stand still and just use basic attacks, the dragon will keep attacking you until you get down to 1 hp. Then, for some reason, the game shows the dragon doing damage, but it actually doesn't and you become virtually immortal unless you use a heavy attack, special move, or you do a dodge roll. It's fun for the first 15 hours, then it gets boring.

reviewText:
As a level editor, Fight The Dragon is excellent, with simple, easily understood UI and an intuitive map editor.
As a diablo-style RPG, the game severely lacks content, story, or skill progression.

It's too easy to find levels that use every monster/mechanic in the game, which leads to everything afterwards feeling repetive. So after 4 or 5 levels or shooting/slashing mobs, collecting keys, and placing barrels on switches to open doors, it gets quite dull.

If you're looking for a chance to make your own (short) RPG dungeons to show off to your friends, this is a fine game to pickup.  But, if you're looking to play through a MP adventure with friends, well, you're better off sticking with games that advertise their game, not their editors.

reviewText:
There's a lot to like about this game - unlimited adventures, fun combat, nice graphics, and a strong developer presence in the forums. It's not perfect though. Community made maps are hit or miss. There's a ton of great content out there, but unfortunately you'll need to wade through quite a bit of clunkers to get to them.

As a single player game, it has a limited life span since each map is pretty much the same monsters/puzzles/traps just in different orders. Once you are able to get multiplayer working for more than 5 minutes, it becomes extremely fun again. I'm not sure if the problem lies with me or the servers, but there were plenty of frustrating moments with either disconnects or just plain not being able to connect at all. The gameplay makes those frustrations worth it though, but beware problems do exist.

UPDATE:
Perhaps I was too harsh in my original review and now I feel bad about it. The game is fun in co-op and has a very neat idea. Some things can be improved upon, but overall I had a fun time playing it. It can get a little repetitive, but it is up to a community to create fun maps for it, although tools provided need a little work and I would LOVE to be able to put more stuff in adventures, right now it is kinda limited.
My initial review was negative and posted after I spent almost 3 hours creating my own adventure and focusing on details only to find out I ran out off points without implementing even 1/3rd of what I wanted and never being able to publish it, because the albeit much needed anti-grind system is flawed in thinking I made an impossible challenge of puting too much traps and enemies in my adventure. Which bummed me out, cuz the whole idea of my adventure was about hard and challenging castle inspired by Dark Souls that can't be rushed. Fighting 2 bosses at a time, running under heavy ranged fire, carefully walking around traps. I've put a lot of effort in it, but ultimately couldn't published it and that really bummed me out because of the time spent designing.

If you're creative type and want some good time with friends in coop in a simple game, this game might be what you want.
Although creating mode is limited, there are still vast variety of adventures that can be created. I really wish you can let your fantasy run free and produce massive and detailed maps with lots of enemies and challenges, so player can sweat a little. But I realise this is not exactly a game about it. It is more simple, more relaxed and easy paced hack'n'slash game with basic controls. It's more of a kids game perhaps.
Whatever the case, I am canging my recommendation, because I feel like I've been unfair in my initial review.

reviewText:
More Impressions @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

(Early Access Impressions)

With random adventures waiting around every corner, Fight the Dragon looks very promising. The aesthetics are rather basic, but the focus is on the adventure and challenges that you‚Äôll face when you go out to level and gear up. The ultimate goal is to go and ‚ÄúFight the Dragon‚Äù (what else?). Whether you‚Äôre looking to kill the dragon or just do some damage to him he‚Äôs got plenty of health do deal with.

When you go out to adventure, you‚Äôll play random levels as you pick which spot you want to go to on the over-world map (or at least that‚Äôs the best way I‚Äôve found to describe it). You can replay levels already completed, but you won‚Äôt get a Dragon Scroll for completing them. (They allow you to fight the big jerky dragon.) You‚Äôll get levels created by the developer (3 Sprockets) and those created by other players. You do get to vote for which maps you liked after you‚Äôve either beaten them or been defeated by them. So far I‚Äôm in the dark of how I want to vote on some of them due to the content in them. I know that certain aspects of them are good, but if I don‚Äôt appreciate them, well‚Ä¶ ah who am I kidding, thumbs down! After all, if you don‚Äôt like it, you don‚Äôt like it. (I like the neutral thumb more.)

The best part of Fight the Dragon for me has to be, hands down, the level editor. I‚Äôm enjoying the heck out of the editor and I started by trying to recreate levels from the N64 game Goldeneye. I‚Äôve since stopped doing that since Fight the Dragon doesn‚Äôt support multiple levels. Without having ability to create a second floor, my creation of ‚ÄúNot The Facility‚Äù has been halted until further progress has been made on the editor. I‚Äôm sure that‚Äôs something they may add in later. Maybe I‚Äôll be able to make taller maps as well. As of now, you can only effectively make a tall one floor house. As for a beginning setup for crafting your own adventures, it works well enough for making dungeons and outside areas. If you‚Äôre willing to work with what you‚Äôve got, there‚Äôs plenty of tools at your disposal to make some fun adventures for you and other players. At the very least, I would appreciate the ability to build higher even if I can‚Äôt make a second floor.

There has been a few levels that remind me of what I‚Äôm not appreciating with some games lately. There‚Äôs been a fad with making games super difficult to bring back the ‚Äúnostalgia of the olden times‚Äù. Some of the levels presented include way to many traps and junk that you‚Äôll almost need prescience to know where to go. Can‚Äôt anyone remember when you just had a fun adventure and it wasn‚Äôt horribly difficult? I remember some games being difficult, but I don‚Äôt think many of those devs went out of their way to get your goat.

On a flip-side, you have the ability to follow creators of your choice. It makes it a little easier to find an adventure you‚Äôll probably enjoy more. However, I still recommend going on random adventures since that‚Äôs probably where the most fun will be, not knowing what you‚Äôre getting yourself into. You may even find yourself on my level. I‚Äôll make more. I‚Äôm pretty happy with how the ‚ÄúTunjair Desert‚Äù map turned out. Since I like to be satisfied with what I make, I‚Äôll be taking my time and not rush anything.

Score: Support This Title!

With the level design loosely reminding me of Minecraft, I felt right at home creating levels. Sharing them is super easy too. There are limits to what you can actually design, but with time they may open up some options with height or creating second levels. The levels created by your fellow Steam people can range from (as much as one would expect) bland to fun to ‚ÄúWhat the ‚Ä¶?‚Äù The fact that you can favorite designers of your choice makes it easier. It‚Äôs rather fun to play through and that stupid dragon is just begging to be stabbed. Fight the Dragon is definitely worth supporting.

reviewText:
TL;DR: The level editor leaves a lot to be desired, and that was the one feature I wanted the game for.  The gameplay on its own sucks, but the loot system is decent enough.  Of course, even the loot system has its issues.

The rest of the review:

It's an Early Access experience, so I wasn't expecting much polish.  There's no content to the story, you just fight the dragon, hence the title.  I was OK with the lack of built-in content, because I thought I could play some user-created content that would actually be interesting.

If you're buying the game for the level editor, stop.  The level editor sucks.  It isn't intuitive.  It has the beginnings of a logic editor with entity links, but you can't really make anything worth playing.  You can't have interactive dialogue with NPCs.  You can't have multi-floor buildings (well, you can if you're very clever with the bridge objects, but I think that's a glitch).  You can't make endless arena maps.  You can't make maps for Steam Workshop, the maps are built into the game instead, so your Steam profile doesn't get to display your map creations.  (Yes, you can make and share skins but that's not really interesting to me.)  Overall, it is just too limited and offers very little in terms of customization.

If you're buying this game just to grind loot all day, have fun.  The loot system promotes replaying missions as efficiently as possible, only focusing on opening chests rather than fighting enemies.  You can build and play your own levels and just place all the enemies in a secluded area, away from everything else, so if you're after loot, I don't think you'll have any issues.

reviewText:
I bought this game during the Steam Summer Sale, figuring if I didn't like it I didn't spend too much money on it.

I fired it up and played a little while, figuring out the combat and loot system, as well as trying out the random and player-made adventures.  The next thing I know, 6 hours had passed and I still wanted to play more!

THIS GAME IS FREAKING AWESOME!

Fight the Dragon is an action hack-n-slash RPG, but one like no other you've ever played.  Sure, you get stat upgrades, tons of loot, and you fight strange mystical creatures.  FtD, however, has something I've yet to see in any other game - player made adventures!  Thousands of them, too, for hours upon endless hours of replayability!  Add to that the four unique character classes, and you're getting far more than your money's worth from this title.

My personal rating?  The graphics have a cute charm to them, and while the controls can be a bit slow or clunky at times, they're very manageable.  The gameplay and replayabiolity is where this title truly shines, however.  I can see myself sinking 100's of hours into this one, and maybe even creating a few adventures of my own!

9/10  This game is PURE GOLD and worth every penny (and then some)!  Pick it up - I promise you won't regret it.

reviewText: The core of this game is actually very solid. It has a good loot system, good mechanics, good enough graphics, combat works well, the dragon concept and loot shrines are great ideas and even the spawn system is spot on. Unfortunately the game just doesn't go far enough to remain interesting. There are only 4 classes and each class has very few abilities and there really isn't much of any customizing to them. The loot shrine is a solid idea but it left me wishing I had something else to spend my gold on that was more interesting. The adventure design system has a really solid core, but unfortunately is just so limiting to what you can do with it that every adventure you play feels exactly the same.\n\nOverall it's a game that gets many of its core ideas right, but the lack of more" to it just leaves you bored with the game after a short time playing it. reviewText:
Early Access Review

A no doubt creative project/game with an interesting concept which suffers from horribly boring gameplay.

In it's core, the game is a basic (and by basic I mean REEEEEEEALLY basic) hack'n'slash style platformer. Feeling like a mix of cheap arcade platformers and a cutesy-minecraft graphics version of Diablo.
Fighting comes down to just slashing away, doing the one or other dodge against bigger enemies or occasionally using a special or heavy attack. Every 'class' comes with slight differences, but I didn't really feel any different when playing as Rogue or Fire Mage.

The main selling point of the game is it's 'infinite level content' by means of providing a level editor. However, after playing a few hours, I've already seen and beaten + figured out simple patterns of attack to take down all of the ~dozen enemy types the game has to offer. And here is exactly the issue: Providing players a Level Editro does NOT give you instant 'ininite content'. It just gives you infinite variations of the exact same 15 enemies placed on the same 30 tilesets. If the game would have given me the possibility to pick enemy core animations, then add in my own values and special modifiers, that would have been interesting... but like this? Boring and EXTREMELY repetitive.
Not to mention trivially easy (even when I accidentally entered a high level map with a level 1 mage. Took some more kiting/time, but that's it).

The concept of the dragon arena is nice. And no doubt, the dragon is a heck of a boss. But that alone does not motivate me to grind through the same enemies hours and hours to come just to beat that boss.


Overall, I'm VERY disappointed with the game, even more so because it's not This is a very early access and lots is to come" but a "It's nearly finished and very playable".

Rating: 2/10
Your money will get you a better hour ratio in ever other game."

reviewText:
The good:

* The game looks very nice. Models and textures are really nice and consistent. Sounds are also good. The GUI, while not particularly intuitive at first, looks great and is very responsive.

The bad:

* By default the game window was not created properly. I had to edit the configuration file (after stumbling across a forum post) to get it to a window of a reasonable size.

* Gameplay is basic and repetitive.

* My first character wasn't saved, apparently because I didn't exit the game properly. This wouldn't be so bad if the starting levels were not the same every time.

It's entirely possible I am not the target audience for this game. The gameplay seems more aimed at a young gamer though the interface and controls are not that simple.

reviewText: I bought this game for myself and some friends because I thought it would be a lovely, quirky game to play. So far I have been nothing but frustrated by the gameplay. Don't get me wrong, it isn't all bad and I do enjoy it. I just find the levels so difficult to complete that it takes the fun out of it for me. The drop items are quite fun, but unless you play a higher difficulty they are crap. The enemies are well animated and create a diverse and dynamic game, unless you play at anything over the easiest difficulty then you get swarmed and die, a lot. There is a good online element as you can play senerios that other members have created, which can result in some interesting storylines. However the game is so difficult to complete that I just cried and now have no energy to try again.\n\nPlay it if you enjoy a challenge and can actually overcome it. Don't play if you have any tendency to rage quit like I do.

reviewText:
This game is fun. The map editing program is extensive and I spent a while making some complicated maps. The game is very basic, you gain levels by playing either creator made maps, your maps or maps of other users and eventually defeat the dragon.

Pros:

Map making is easy and fun, and you can accomplish a good amount in a short time.

The gameplay is pretty fluid, although sometimes when you try to hit an enemy with a sword nothing happens. That could just be a miss on the attack, but it isn't indicated.

The loot system reminds me of Borderlands.

The dragon is VERY tough to beat. After pouring several hours into leveling up and getting good gear to fight the dragon I've still only been able to knock out a few thousand health from it per battle. It starts out with a million health, but health doesn't regenerate in between battles, so the damage you do to it is permanent. If you get health regenerating equipment and are willing to run around the map for about 48 hours to avoid attacks while you heal, then you could beat the dragon in one sitting, but I do not recommend you try.

Cons:

Once a moderator accuses your map of being an exploit, it seems they never go back to unban it after you edit it. For example, I built a map that was a straight shot from beginning to end with a couple hundred rats and skeletons to fight. It was by no means an easy map. I would usually beat it with just a single life left. Because of Its simplicity it was banned for being a grinding exploit, and now that I edited it to include Minotaurs (which easily knock a player off my map, thereby increasing the difficulty greatly) It's still in review.

Although bugs are fixed quickly and little things are added here and there, no real new content has shown up to my knowledge since my purchase of the game a few months ago. The game's replay value sinks quickly after you unlock your final ability and realize the only thing you have left to do is suffer through endless generic hours of gameplay to get a bit stronger to stand up to the dragon better.

You can't just go and challenge the dragon whenever you want. You need a scroll, and to get it you need to play a new map. If you don't have an internet connection, you will run out of scrolls quickly and won't be able to play the main purpose of the game.


Overall, the game is good, and I recommend it if you're willing to do the same thing for a while in order ot beat that pesky dragon, and if you're willing to put up with moderators banning you for exploiting, then not giving you a second chance. Don't mess up in map editing, or you'll end up like me, the evil Bonticune.

Things I'd like to see:

A multiplayer option to fight the dragon with. Maybe a dragon whose health resets after each battle, and some prize system if you do a certain amount of damage.

Different equipment when you deal enough damage to the dragon. The time limit rings are good for the few minutes you get them, but the rings that last for even as high as an hour and a half are gone a lot quicker than people would think.

A difficulty higher than extreme. I like heavy combat in my games, and with health regen equipment the game has become too easy.

The ability to have bosses speak before they attack.

The field of views for enemies increased (if the player makes it so while editing)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[After having trouble getting started, the developers got involved (in Steam community, I like it) and helped me out. Turns out the issue was the user and not the programming, sorry. Maybe that information should have been made more public? In my defense, many Linux ports are just broken, it's getting tiresome, luckily devs were on the case or I might have missed this indie gem!]

Experience on Linux:

+ Works.
+ High developer interaction, even in Steam community. Good!
+ This IS indeed the way to showcase a new game under development on Linux.

The game:
As expected in early access, a few key features are missing regarding controls, but it seems the devs are keen on making this a good game so we may see lots of polishing up in the near future.
The game itself isn't what top end console gamers would consider good looking, but I like the artstyle. It reminds me of Egoboo (obscure title) and has that adventure feeling Neverwinter Nights used to offer. This game also has a top down platformer mechanic, much like some Zelda titles, but combines it with deeper RPG elements that we are all familiar with (XP, levels, character development, items, etc). The music is very good, it sets the tone of the game perfectly.
All in all, the game delivers on every point of my expectations. If you like adventure, magic, treasure and dragons, this is your buy. Oh, it also has the number one RPG enemy: rats!

Score:
3/5 (still early access, with all the features in place I bet this will be a high 4 or even a 5)

My only qualm is with the overall content of the game. Would love to see some additional assets for adventure creation, including monsters, props, textures, environments, skyboxes, etc. There's a lot that could be expanded upon here, and I'm sure that they'll keep adding features to make adventures more exciting to play - and to create!

reviewText:
GET IT WHILE IT'S ON SALE FOR 75% OFF, YOU WON'T REGRET A SINGLE THING!!!

This is quite literally my childhood dream come true. It has aspects from 3 games that I deeply cherrished as a little kid, and still do: Gauntlet, Diablo & LittleBigPlanet. I've played COUNTLESS hours of each game in the past, and I plan on spending quite some time on this one.

Aside from the personal mumbo-jumbo, this game is a hack 'n' slash RPG with a nostalgic dungeon crawl feel to it. The character customization is pretty neat, especially since there's skins and stuff you can get off of the Steam Workshop. Plus, there's a variety of different armors and weapons you can get, which adds onto the already wide variety of character customizations. The BIGGEST factor of the game that is certainly astounding is the in-game level editor, which lets you make your own levels and publish it for anybody to play. Just as an honorable mention, it also has FULL controller support, as well as splitscreen co-op, so it 100% makes an astounding game to just mess around with when you have a friend over. Not only is it splitscreen co-op, but it's co-op both online worldwide and through LAN!

Though, I gotta include the very few things I don't particularly like about this game. The fact that you can't use lowercase letters SO IT ALWAYS LOOKS LIKE YOU'RE SHOUTING, and how when you're hopping from ledge to ledge and you bump into a wall something, you basically go straight down as soon as you hit it. Other than those two things, I have no complaints about this game!

reviewText:
There is an indescribable charm about this game that I just can't get over. I picked it up during the Summer Sale because it was less than three bucks. My expectations going in were for an hour-or-two-throwaway, barely finished product.

What I got instead has enthralled me so much the past two days. I can play for five minutes or get lost in a two-hour binge. The maps are long enough to feel detailed but short enough to complete in one sitting. Combat can get repetitive but with new and better loot dropping here and there, from enemies and chests, I didn't really care; it's good, plain fun. There are four classes with individual spells and special abilities - a fighter, fire mage, ice mage and rogue - but I've only played as an Ice Wizard" up to this point without losing any interest or even gaining a desire to try other classes. I'm having too much fun with this one.

There's also a map/adventure/campaign editor where you can create your own landscapes
